Author: gizmo
Content:
The main problem is that most programmers never experience Unicode problems themselves. 7 bits is enough for most of us. So we only start using Unicode when the pain caused by incessant nagging exceeds the pain of implementing Unicode. So we never fix the Unicode problems out of curiosity, we fix them because people make us. No wonder we never learn.

The second problem is that we don't understand Unicode. Yes, we know that 7 bits isn't quite enough to represent all different characters, and that you have utf-8 and UTC, and so forth, but we really don't care enought to find out how it really works. We read some articles online, and we start using wchar_t / TCHAR instead of char, but that's basically it. Why bother with Unicode when you can simply write 'resume' instead of 'résumé'? Nobody cares.

That's what it boils down to:

Nobody really cares. So it doesn't get fixed.

The only mystery is why people still expect Unicode support to "just happen".

Author: wave
Title: Ten XML Schemas you should know

Author: edw519
Content:
The method is out of sync with how humans work.

Wrong.

The method works perfectly when done properly. Because it's perfectly in sync with how humans work.

So why don't most people know how? 2 possible reasons:

- All we really have to do is stay one step ahead of the users. So we don't have to be very good.

- The field is so young we still don't have adequate well-established standards and procedures. Imagine "release early and often" as the standards for law, medicine, or bridge building.

I've heard this argument too many times from people who have never done it right so they think it can't be done.

Author: rcraswell
Content: In Netflix's case it's not that baseline recommendation (whether based on collaborative filtering or something else) is such a hard problem, it's that getting something statistically better than what they have is so hard.  Decent recommendation based on CF was a well-understood problem over ten years ago.

Author: tstegart
Content: What would you say changing your links from using underscores to hyphens would be? Is that gaming the system, or making a better website? I mean, from a programming perspective, it doesn't sound like it makes much difference, but from an SEO perspective, it makes a huge difference. Google recognizes words when they're hyphenated, but not necessarily when they're underscored. Your rankings will probably improve just by doing that. Its simple things like that that programmers should be aware of, and its not really gaming the system, its programming to match what Google recognizes.
